Cold Blood: The Merchant's Daughter

A young white dragon has claimed the high mountain pass as its hunting ground. When a merchant's daughter goes missing, heroes must brave rushing waters, treacherous cliffs, and a creature that lurks beneath the surface to save her from becoming the dragon's next meal.

This encounter is designed for a party of four to five characters of 6th or 7th level. It takes place in an alpine river crossing during late autumn or early winter, when the mountain winds howl and the water runs ice-cold from glacial melt.

A Note on Terrain

This encounter is designed around a specific battlemap featuring a river with multiple crossing points, cliff walls of varying heights, and limited entry/exit points. The tactical complexity comes from creatures that exploit each terrain feature—the dragon controls the air and northern ford, the troll ambushes from the western cliffs, and the water weird lurks in the deep water where escape is nearly impossible.

For the DM

This adventure is structured to help you handle Tier 2 Play (Levels 5-10). At this level, characters have powerful resources (Flight, Fireball, Revivify). The challenge here isn't just high HP monsters, but Terrain and Tactical Disadvantage. Read the DM Guide: Teaching Tier 2 Combat page at the end of this journal for specific advice!

Adventure Hook

The Merchant's Daughter

In the village of Frosthollow, the party encounters Aldric Vane, a wealthy but desperate fur merchant.

"Three days ago, my daughter Mira took the high pass with two of my best guards. Stubborn girl. Only one guard returned, half-frozen and rambling about a white death from the sky." Aldric's eyes dart around nervously. "She was wearing a... family heirloom. A heavy sapphire necklace. Please, bring her back. And the necklace. I'll pay 800 gold pieces, and grant you this cloak of elvenkind."

A successful [[/save ability=wis dc=14]] (&Reference[skill=ins]) reveals Aldric is hiding something about the necklace—he seems almost as worried about the jewelry as he is about his daughter.

What Really Happened

Cryovain (Young White Dragon) attacked the group at the ford. He killed one guard and snatched Mira. Mira, realizing the dragon was distracted, dropped the glowing Sapphire Necklace into the river, hoping to hide it.

Big mistake. The necklace is a Shard of the River King (Elementals). Its presence in the water summoned and bound a Water Weird to the location. The Weird is now a mindless guardian of the deeps, attacking anything that enters. The Dragon and Troll don't know why the "water spirit" is there, but they use it as a trap!

The Approach: Frozen Pass

Before reaching the battlemap, the party must traverse the treacherous high pass as a storm closes in. This is a Skill Challenge designed to drain resources or HP before the boss fight.

The Challenge

Goal: Navigate the cliffside path before the blizzard hits full force.
Difficulty: The party needs 4 Successes before 3 Failures.
DC: 14 (Level 6-7 standard)

Ask the players how they contribute. Examples:

  • Survival (Wis): finding the stable path under the snow.
  • Athletics (Str): clearing a fallen boulder or helping an ally climb.
  • Nature (Int): predicting wind gusts to time movement.
  • Perception (Wis): spotting loose ice.
  • Spells: Spending a spell slot of 2nd level or higher grants an automatic success.

Consequences

Victory (4 Successes): The party arrives at the Scene safely, just ahead of the storm.

Failure (3 Failures): The blizzard catches them on the exposed ridge. Each character takes [[/r 2d6]] cold damage and must succeed on a [[/save ability=con dc=14]] or gain 1 Level of Exhaustion. They arrive at the Scene effectively "Ambushed" (enemies are alert).

The River Crossing

The encounter takes place at a river valley carved between snow-dusted peaks. The terrain is designed to split the party, create difficult choices, and reward tactical thinking.

General Features

Wind. Strong winds blow through the valley. Ranged weapon attacks across the river (a distance of 30-50 feet) are made with disadvantage.

Terrain.

  • Northern Ford: Safe crossing (Difficult Terrain).
  • The Deeps (Trapped): 15-20ft deep. Cold water (Con DC 12 or -10ft speed). Water Weird Lair.
  • Rapids: Str Save DC 12 or swept 20ft downstream and Prone.
  • Cliffs: Impassable from the water side (Smooth). Western cliff (18ft) offers high ground.

Creatures Strategy

Cryovain (Young White Dragon)

Role: Artillery / Harasser.
Tactics: Starts perched high. Uses Cold Breath on clustered groups, then flies out of reach (Verticality!). If Breath is recharging, he uses Hit-and-Run bite attacks. He is smart enough to stay out of melee range of the Paladin or Barbarian.

Grimjaw (Troll)

Role: Brute / Controller.
Tactics: Hides behind the Western Cliff. Ambush! He doesn't just attack; he uses the Shove action to push players off the 9ft cliff into the Deeps. He knows the "Water Spirit" lives there.

Water Weird

Role: Trap.
Tactics: Bound to the Sapphire Necklace at the bottom of the Deeps. It attacks anyone entering the water.
Twist: If a player dives to the bottom (Athletics DC 12) and retrieves the necklace (Investigation DC 15), they can use an Action to command the Weird to "Attack the Dragon!" or "Let us pass!"

Running the Encounter

Arrival Text: "The wind hits you first—a bitter, howling thing. Before you spreads a river valley... It feels like a place where things come to die."

The Tactical Trap

This encounter is designed to teach players (and DMs) about positioning.
1. Dragon baits players forward.
2. Troll shoves them into the Deeps.
3. Water Weird grapples and drowns them.
4. Rapids sweep survivors downstream, splitting the party.

Counter-Play: Intelligent players will use the terrain too! Ranged attacks from cover, setting the Troll on fire to panic him, or diving for the Necklace to turn the Water Weird into an ally.

Conclusion

Victory: Saving Mira earns 800gp and the cloak of elvenkind. If they return the Necklace, Aldric reveals it is indeed magical (a minor elemental summoning focus) and lets them keep it as a bonus reward!

Failure: If they retreat, Mira dies. The Dragon becomes a recurring villain in the region.

DM Guide: Teaching Tier 2 Combat

Running high-level D&D combat can be daunting. Here is why this encounter is built this way:

1. Action Economy & The Boss

A solo Dragon usually dies in 1 round against Level 6 PC's because the party has 4-5 actions for every 1 of the Dragon's.
The Fix: We added "Minions" (The Troll and Water Weird). They force the party to split their attention/attacks. Lesson: Never run a solo boss without Legendary Actions or Minions.

2. The Environment is an Enemy

Damage isn't the only threat. The Rapids separate the Healer from the Tank. The Cliffs prevent the Paladin from reaching the Dragon.
Lesson: Use terrain to disrupt the players' "standard operating procedure".

3. Drain Resources First

The "Frozen Pass" skill challenge exists to make players use spell slots or take damage before initiative is rolled.
Lesson: A fully rested party is unstoppable. Chip away at them first.
